title: 107_hr1181
content: The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is a new law that provides a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" offers a tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage for individuals, their spouses, and dependents. The credit is limited by monthly caps for eligible coverage months. The tax credit for health insurance coverage under the "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" is limited by monthly caps for eligible coverage months, with a maximum amount of $1,500 per individual per month and a limit of 2 individuals per taxpayer. The tax credit for health insurance coverage is limited to $1,500 per individual per month, with a maximum of 2 individuals per taxpayer. Married individuals who do not file joint returns are subject to special rules. The tax credit for health insurance coverage is limited to $1,500 per individual per month, with a maximum of 2 individuals per taxpayer. Special rules apply to married individuals who do not file joint returns. Only the individual who does not live apart from their spouse during the taxable year may be considered for the tax credit. Eligible coverage month is defined as any month where the individual meets certain criteria. The term 'eligible coverage month' refers to a month where an individual is covered by qualified health insurance paid by the taxpayer, after a 12-month period without such coverage. The individual must have been without qualified health insurance and ineligible for an employer-provided group health plan from January 1, 2002, to be eligible for a tax credit. The credit amount is reduced based on adjusted gross income. The tax credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year. The tax credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year, calculated as a ratio to the excess of the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income over the applicable dollar amount, divided by $10,000. "The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is defined as adjusted gross income plus any excluded amounts under specific sections. Amounts not multiples of $10 are rounded down. The 'applicable dollar amount' is $60,000 for certain taxpayers." "The applicable dollar amount for qualified health insurance coverage is $60,000 for taxpayers covering more than 1 individual, and $30,000 for other cases or married individuals filing separately." For purposes of determining qualified health insurance, marital status is determined under section 7703. Qualified health insurance refers to insurance that constitutes medical care, excluding insurance with coverage mainly of excepted benefits described in section 9832(c). The term 'qualified health insurance' refers to insurance that constitutes medical care, excluding coverage where less than 50 percent of the cost is borne by the taxpayer. No credit is allowed for amounts paid under certain government-provided programs. No credit shall be allowed under this section for amounts paid under specific government-provided programs, including titles XVIII, XIX, or XXI of the Social Security Act, chapter 55 of title 10, United States Code, chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, or the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. Coverage under specific government-provided programs such as chapter 55 of title 10, United States Code, chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, or the Indian Health Care Improvement Act is considered as coverage under qualified health insurance for eligibility purposes. No credit is allowed for amounts paid for qualified health insurance if taken into account for other deductions. Special rules apply to the tax credit for qualified health insurance. No credit is allowed if the amount paid for health insurance is used for other deductions. The credit is also denied to dependents if a deduction is allowed to another taxpayer for the same taxable year. Inflation adjustment for tax deductions under section 151 is applicable for taxable years starting after 2002, with dollar amounts adjusted based on the cost-of-living. The dollar amounts in subsection (c)(3) are increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $100, it is rounded accordingly. The dollar amounts in subsection (c)(3) are increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. If any adjusted amount is not a multiple of $100, it shall be rounded to the next lowest multiple of $100. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. SEC. 25B amends health insurance costs for previously uninsured individuals. Effective date is after December 31, 2001. SEC. 3 introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs for employees and self-employed individuals under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs for individuals, their spouse, and dependents is allowed under section 25B(d). Any amount paid for this insurance cannot be used for deductions under other sections. The deduction is not allowed for self-employment tax purposes. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is not allowed for self-employment tax purposes and cannot be used in computing deductions under section 162(l) or 213(a). It also does not affect an individual's net earnings from self-employment. Amendments to section 62 of the Code include adding the deduction for health insurance costs.
